### Description

I'm running an ibft network (started at v 1.4.2, upgraded to 1.4.6) on with nodes in GKE and AKS. 
In each cloud provider, we run 1 validator, and 2 rpc nodes.

<details>

We sent a bunch of transactions and overloaded the rpc nodes in some way. 
We saw OOM errors (both in Besu and in k8s) so we increased memory (5g) and cpu limits (4cpu) and the Xmx and Xms settings to 4g.

The validators never failed in any way.

On some nodes we deleted the DB and synced again, on others de did not.

All nodes after a restart/recreate boot, resync and follow the chain for a short while. Then they start failing with:

We have the sneaking suspicion that a user pushed a large value in a contract, and the errors are coming from trying to get these values out of the jsonrpc interface.

The errors we currently get in our code, which correlates roughly to the errors in the Besu logs

```
The value of "offset" is out of range. It must be >= 0 && <= 17825792. Received 17825795
```

```
timeout
```

It looks like the eth_call rpc is indeed taking too much time.  My gut is that it is related to the number of sload operations and not the single large value.  Is the particular contract available for us to examine?

This reminds me of the contracted that violated state, , 0x03 out of gas

```
 2020-06-19 16:45:29.538+00:00 | vertx-blocked-thread-checker | WARN  | BlockedThreadChecker | Thread Thread[vert.x-worker-thread-11,5,main]=Thread[vert.x-worker-thread-11,5,main] has been blocked for 219643 ms, time limit is 60000 ms 
```
I would recommend a paginated variant of getContents where either an explicit sub-range of the array is returned.

I upgraded to bigger machines and SSD disks, but the query keeps being 300+ seconds long. On an infrastructure level, there is nothing more I can do.

Will implement the pagination next unless anyone has a better idea?

What is the scale of the response?  i.e.How many items are in that array?  We are considering some radical DB changes on the back end so that number would be helpful in determining if this is an issue of trie-climbing to get all the values or some other problem.

Sorry, I missed this question. I do not have exact numbers anymore, but it was about 2000 items and serialized as JSON they went over the 16MB MongoDB document limit. So I only know more then 2k and together more than 16mb in space (in one response, so this was a bad query / implementation anyway from my side)

I'm running into the same issue @shemnon
